gw.pl.util.webservices

Class APILocator

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.pl.util.webservices.APILocator

  • public class APILocator
extends java.lang.Object
    APILocator is a utility class that simplifies getting a handle to, and authenticating with, a remote SOAP API [web-service] published by a Guidewire server.

    • Method Detail

      • getAuthenticatedProxy

        public static java.lang.Object getAuthenticatedProxy(java.lang.Class apiClass,
                                     java.lang.String serverURL,
                                     java.lang.String userName,
                                     java.lang.String password)
                                              throws javax.xml.rpc.ServiceException
        Returns an authenticated proxy of the given type to a remote SOAP API [web-service] published by a Guidewire server.

        Authentication
        The proxy is wrapped by an authentication handler which manages authentication for all SOAP request made using the proxy. If the server is non-responsive the handler will attempt to re-authenticated up to 3 times before failing. If your session times-out due to inactivity the handler will transparently re-authenticate you.

        Proxy Pooling
        Every proxy is thread-safe, allowing multiple threads to share the same proxy instance. Under the covers each proxy is taken from a static pool of proxies at request time, the actual object returned by this method is simply a handle to this pool. The proxy is leased from the pool when you initiate a SOAP request and returned to the pool when your request completes. The proxies themselves are lazily created, the first time a proxy of a particular type is requested it will be minted. A proxy is identified by its API class, server, and authentication credentials. If two or more threads require a proxy of the same type at the same time additional proxy instances will be minted to satisfy all the concurrent requests.

        Clean-up
        When your program finishes using its proxy or proxies you should logout each proxy using releaseAndLogoutAllProxies(). This will release every proxy in the proxy pool. If you only want to release your current proxy you can cast the proxy to SOAPAuthenticatedProxy and call logout(). Either operation will logout your current session on the server.

        SOAP Headers
        This method will manage clearing any SOAP headers it uses related to authentication. If you explicitly set any special SOAP headers using SOAPOutboundHandler, such as Globals.GW_TRANSACTION_ID_PROPERTY, you'll need to explicitly clear the header yourself when finished. One way to accomplish this is through a try finally code block: 

         try {
   SOAPOutboundHandler.setHeader(
     SOAPOutboundHandler.GW_TRANSACTION_ID_PROPERTY, "transID");
   // Execute SOAP request within the context of the supplied
   soapAPIProxy.executeSOAPRequest();
 } finally {
   SOAPOutboundHandler.clear();
 }
        SOAP headers are set on a per-thread context.
        Parameters:
        apiClass - The SOAP API interface to which you want a handle
        serverURL - URL of the remote Guidewire server
        userName - Username of user to authenticate
        password - Password of user to authenticate
        Returns:
        A thread-safe proxy to the remote SOAP API
        Throws:
        javax.xml.rpc.ServiceException

      • getUnauthenticatedProxy

        public static java.lang.Object getUnauthenticatedProxy(java.lang.Class apiClass,
                                       java.lang.String serverURL,
                                       java.lang.String userName,
                                       java.lang.String password)
                                                throws javax.xml.rpc.ServiceException
        Returns an unauthenticated proxy of the given type to a remote SOAP API [web-service] published by a Guidewire server.

        Authentication
        The proxy wrapped by an authentication handler. This proxy will set the correct credentials for the soap call to authenticate itself. And the call will be non-session based.

        Proxy Pooling
        Every proxy is thread-safe, allowing multiple threads to share the same proxy instance. Under the covers each proxy is taken from a static pool of proxies at request time, the actual object returned by this method is simply a handle to this pool. The proxy is leased from the pool when you initiate a SOAP request and returned to the pool when your request completes. The proxies themselves are lazily created, the first time a proxy of a particular type is requested it will be minted. A proxy is identified by its API class and server. Unlike getAuthenticatedProxy(Class, String, String, String) this proxy is NOT identified also identified by the user credentials. If two or more threads require a proxy of the same type at the same time additional proxy instances will be minted to satisfy all the concurrent requests.

        No Clean-up
        After each invocation, each proxy will automatically release itself (hence non-conversational).

        SOAP Headers
        This method will manage clearing any SOAP headers it uses related to authentication. If you explicitly set any special SOAP headers using SOAPOutboundHandler, such as Globals.GW_TRANSACTION_ID_PROPERTY, you'll need to explicitly clear the header yourself when finished. One way to accomplish this is through a try finally code block: 

         try {
   SOAPOutboundHandler.setHeader(
     SOAPOutboundHandler.GW_TRANSACTION_ID_PROPERTY, "transID");
   // Execute SOAP request within the context of the supplied
   soapAPIProxy.executeSOAPRequest();
 } finally {
   SOAPOutboundHandler.clear();
 }
        SOAP headers are set on a per-thread context.
        Parameters:
        apiClass - The SOAP API interface to which you want a handle
        serverURL - URL of the remote Guidewire server
        userName - Username of user to authenticate
        password - Password of user to authenticate
        Returns:
        A thread-safe proxy to the remote SOAP API
        Throws:
        javax.xml.rpc.ServiceException

      • executeSOAPOperation

        public static java.lang.Object executeSOAPOperation(GWSOAPOperation operation)
        Deprecated. Use getAuthenticatedProxy(Class, String, String, String)
        NOTE:This method has been deprecated, use getAuthenticatedProxy(Class, String, String, String) instead.

        Executes the given soap operation. Upon completion of the operation the proxies used by the operation are returned to the pool.

        You'll need to implementation an operation similar to implementing a java.lang.Runnable. 

         public class DoSomeSOAPOperation implements GWSOAPOperation {
  public Object run(GWSOAPProvider provider) {
      IClaimAPI claimAPI = (IClaimAPI) provider.getProxy(....);
      IUserAPI userAPI = (IUserAPI) provider.getProxy(...);
      claimAPI.xxx()
      Object results = userAPI.xxx()
      return resutls;
  }
 }
 
        
 public void main() {
    Object results = APILocator.executeSOAPOperation(new
 DoSomeSOAPOperation());
    APILocator.releaseAndLogoutAllProxies();
 }

        Clean-up
        See getAuthenticatedProxy(Class, String, String, String) for clean-up process as the same clean-up rules apply.

        Parameters:
        operation - Operation to execute
        Returns:
        Return value of this method will be the return value of operation.run()

      • releaseAndLogoutAllProxies

        public static void releaseAndLogoutAllProxies()
        Releases all proxies and logs them out and clears all SOAP headers associated with this thread. This should be called when your program exists, not after each SOAP request.
